info.game_comments: Pre-empted in many markets in its original run for September 11th news coverage.  Aired on GSN on 2005-06-21.

(1, 1).clue: Gauguin's mom was Peruvian, & from 1851 to 1855 he lived with her in this capital city

(3, 1).clue: This projectile's name comes from the Late Latin for "pomegranate"

(4, 1).clue: Isolated in 1983, the virus that causes AIDS is known today by this acronym

(5, 1).clue: In his heredity experiments this 19th century monk cross-pollinated garden pea plants

(6, 1).clue: A mint-tasting compound from peppermint oil

(1, 2).clue: In 1766 George Stubbs, a noted painter of these animals, published a book on their anatomy

(2, 2).clue: In 1976 Billy Joel was in this city's "state of mind"

(3, 2).clue: These rifle additions gained their first prominence in the 17th century

(4, 2).clue: Seeing Koplik's spots on the inside of your cheeks is a sign you've "spotted" this viral infection

(5, 2).clue: It's the husk that peas come in & may be edible

(1, 3).clue: Masterpieces in this Manhattan museum include "Starry Night" & "Les Demoiselles d'Avignon"

(2, 3).clue: In a 1932 standard, it's the city you "shuffle off to"

(3, 3).clue: A 15th-century drawing of the medieval variety of this siege weapon is seen here

(4, 3).clue: It's the B form of this inflammation of the liver that's spread by some kinds of personal contact

(5, 3).clue: This sea-faring fashion seen here is popular with sailors & fishermen

(1, 4).clue: This abstract artist's method of applying paint, as in "Autumn Rhythm", earned him the nickname "Jack the Dripper"

(2, 4).clue: The song "Way Down Yonder In" this city goes way back to 1922

(3, 4).clue: Alphanumeric designation of the American standard used in Vietnam, seen here

(4, 4).clue: A fatal form of blood poisoning in cattle, or the group that recorded the 1985 album "Spreading the Disease"

(5, 4).clue: In an Edward Lear nonsense poem, this title duo goes to sea in a pea-green boat

(1, 5).clue: This American woman scoffed at charges that her close-up paintings of flowers had sexual imagery

(2, 5).clue: Glen Campbell had hits all over the map: Phoenix, Wichita & this Texas city

(3, 5).clue: It's the impressive weapon seen here that can take off & land vertically

(4, 5).clue: This lung disease, isolated in 1882, has been found in an ancient mummy, so there should be hieroglyphic Christmas Seals

(5, 5).clue: Widely cultivated for their edible seeds, these peas are also called garbanzos

(1, 1).clue: Traveling on foot, he planted apple orchards all over the Middle West

(2, 1).clue: (Hi, I'm Seth Green.)  He played my dad in both of the "Austin Powers" movies

(4, 1).clue: The type of establishment represented here, or a style of four-part harmony singing

(5, 1).clue: At the Academy, Plato nicknamed this student "The Reader" because of his love of books

(6, 1).clue: Technically, it's superfluous to use this word after "chili"

(1, 2).clue: Febold Feboldson was a giant who performed amazing feats on the plains of Nebraska & this "Sunflower State"

(2, 2).clue: Anne Archer received an Oscar nomination for playing Michael Douglas' wife in this thriller

(4, 2).clue: A singing style practiced in Tuva in Central Asia is named for this body part, which must get "sore"

(5, 2).clue: Known for his theory of right triangles, he believed that the planets create their own sounds in their orbits

(6, 2).clue: This word found on signs before "pit" & "trench" is superfluous; it's an inherent quality of pits & trenches

(1, 3).clue: This lumberjack's tales appeared in a 1914 booklet published by the Red River Lumber Company of Minneapolis

(2, 3).clue: Elvis made his feature film debut as Clint Reno in this 1956 western

(4, 3).clue: Tremolo is sometimes used synonymously with this other Italian term for a "quavering" effect

(5, 3).clue: Of the 23 Ptolemys who ruled Egypt, she was the only one who bothered to learn the Egyptian language

(6, 3).clue: A Toronto institution is somewhat redundantly named this "for Sick Children"

(1, 4).clue: Folk tales of this legendary keelboatman began appearing shortly after his 1823 death

(2, 4).clue: Private dick Steve Martin interacts with clips from '40s noir films in this 1982 crime comedy

(4, 4).clue: In 1933 it had to be Bing Crosby who introduced the song "Learn To" do this

(5, 4).clue: In 221 B.C. he took command of the Carthaginian Army in Spain from his brother-in-law

(6, 4).clue: It's redundant to refer to this "system of measurement", since the word means "relating to measurement"

(1, 5).clue: This Texas cowboy who used a Bowie knife as a teething ring was created by journalist Edward O'Reilly in 1923

(2, 5).clue: In a 1982 movie, Jessica Lange played this actress of the '30s & '40s who was institutionalized & lobotomized

(3, 5).correct response: Low Countries (or the Netherlands or Holland)

(4, 5).clue: Appropriate nickname of singer Jay Hawkins, heard here

(5, 5).clue: The "Histories" of this "Father of History" told of the Persian Empire's invasions of Greece in 490 & 480 B.C.

(6, 5).clue: This common legal order to terminate an activity includes 2 synonyms for "stop"

(0, 0).clue: Of the U.S. states with active volcanos, this state is farthest south
